citations.narrative:
At the time of the inspection, there were multiple areas in the enclosures housing dogs where the surface layer of paint
has chipped and peeled away, exposing the materials underneath. Rough, uneven surfaces cannot be readily cleaned
and sanitized and may therefore harbor pathogens that can cause disease in these animals. The facility must ensure that
all surfaces in contact with the dogs can be cleaned and sanitized or be replaceable when worn or soiled. To be corrected
by November 11, 2025.

There are several dogs currently on nebulization treatments for respiratory symptoms, as directed by the attending
veterinarian. These treatments are to be administered three times per day according to the attending veterinarian's
instructions. According to the licensee, these treatments are being administered as directed. However, some of the
nebulization treatments were not documented as being given in three of the dogs' medical records. Incomplete medical
records prevent APHIS officials from verifying that treatments are being administered exactly as directed by the attending
veterinarian. The facility must ensure that medical records for dogs are complete, including identification, any problems
identified, treatment plans, the names and dates of treatments administered, and other relevant findings. To be corrected
by September 2, 2025.

The material coating the walls in enclosures housing parakeets, sun conures, and lovebirds has peeled away in several
areas, exposing the uneven, rusted surface beneath. Rusted and uneven surfaces cannot be readily cleaned and
sanitized, potentially exposing these animals to pathogens that can cause disease. The facility must ensure that all
surfaces in contact with the birds can be readily cleaned and sanitized or replaced when worn or soiled. To be corrected
by November 11, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.6(a)(2)(ix) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
At the time of the inspection, there were multiple areas in the enclosures housing dogs where the surface layer of paint 
has chipped and peeled away, exposing the materials underneath. Rough, uneven surfaces cannot be readily cleaned 
and sanitized and may therefore harbor pathogens that can cause disease in these animals. The facility must ensure that 
all surfaces in contact with the dogs can be cleaned and sanitized or be replaceable when worn or soiled. To be corrected 
by November 11, 2025. 
3.13(b)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
There are several dogs currently on nebulization treatments for respiratory symptoms, as directed by the attending 
veterinarian. These treatments are to be administered three times per day according to the attending veterinarian's 
instructions. According to the licensee, these treatments are being administered as directed. However, some of the 
nebulization treatments were not documented as being given in three of the dogs' medical records. Incomplete medical 
records prevent APHIS officials from verifying that treatments are being administered exactly as directed by the attending 
veterinarian. The facility must ensure that medical records for dogs are complete, including identification, any problems 
identified, treatment plans, the names and dates of treatments administered, and other relevant findings. To be corrected 
by September 2, 2025. 
3.153(a)(1)(ix) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
The material coating the walls in enclosures housing parakeets, sun conures, and lovebirds has peeled away in several 
areas, exposing the uneven, rusted surface beneath. Rusted and uneven surfaces cannot be readily cleaned and 
sanitized, potentially exposing these animals to pathogens that can cause disease. The facility must ensure that all 
surfaces in contact with the birds can be readily cleaned and sanitized or replaced when worn or soiled. To be corrected 
by November 11, 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.

n
